answers: For First Year Pharm. D. for All India Candidature Candidates, preference is given to candidates obtaining a non-zero positive score in the National Eligibility cum Entrance Test (NEET) over candidates who obtained a non-zero score in MHT-CET 2025.

questions: What are the minimum marks required in 10+2 for First Year Architecture for Maharashtra State Candidature Candidates?
answers: For First Year Architecture, Maharashtra State Candidature Candidates must have at least 50% aggregate marks (45% for Reserved Categories, EWS, and PwD candidates belonging to Maharashtra State only) in Physics, Chemistry, and Mathematics in 10+2, and also at least 50% aggregate marks (45% for Reserved Categories, EWS, and PwD candidates belonging to Maharashtra State only) in the 10+2 level examination. They also need to qualify an aptitude test in architecture conducted either by NTA (i.e., JEE) or NATA conducted by the Council of Architecture.

questions: Which aptitude tests are required for First Year Architecture admission?
answers: For First Year Architecture admission, candidates need to qualify an aptitude test in architecture conducted either by NTA (i.e., JEE) or NATA conducted by the Council of Architecture.

Planning) for Maharashtra State Candidature Candidates, Mathematics is a compulsory subject in the 10+2 examination, along with any two subjects out of Physics, Chemistry, Computer Science, Electronics, Information Technology, Biology, Informatics Practices, Biotechnology, Technical Vocational subject, Agriculture, Engineering Graphics, Business Studies, or Entrepreneurship.

questions: What is the minimum aggregate percentage required in 10+2 for Bachelor of Planning for Maharashtra State Candidature Candidates?

questions: Which entrance exam score is preferred for Bachelor of Planning for All India Candidature Candidates?

questions: What happens if marks change due to verification for admission through CAP?
answers: If marks in the qualifying examination are modified due to verification and certified by the concerned Appropriate Authority or Board, the changes must be reported to the Competent Authority for admission through CAP or its designated representatives before 5 p.m. on the day of the final merit list display.

questions: How is the percentage of marks calculated for deciding eligibility?
answers: The percentage of marks is calculated by rounding off to the nearest integer. For example, 44.50% to 44.99% rounds to 45%, and 44.01% to 44.49% rounds to 44%.

questions: How are marks handled if an individual subjects maximum marks are not 100?
answers: If the maximum marks in an individual subject are not 100, the marks are converted out of 100 without rounding. If the sum of converted marks has a fraction, it's considered up to two decimal places for calculating the overall percentage (considering maximum marks as 300). Rounding is then applied as per the general rule for eligibility.

questions: What is required if letter grades are assigned instead of marks in qualifying examinations?
answers: If letter grades are assigned at SSC, HSC, Diploma, Bachelor of Science, or equivalent examinations, the candidate must submit a certificate of conversion of letter grades into equivalent marks from the concerned competent authority or Board at the time of Application Form submission. Eligibility will be decided based on these equivalent marks.

questions: What happens if a candidate reappears for the qualifying examination with all subjects?
answers: If a candidate reappears for the qualifying examination with all subjects, only the marks obtained in the latest examination will be considered.

questions: How are grades or marks considered for eligibility based on the degree class awarded?
answers: The Grades or Marks are considered based on which the Class of Degree is awarded by the respective University or Board.

questions: How is the merit list prepared for First Year Engineering and Technology (B.E. / B. Tech) for HSC Candidates?
answers: The merit list for HSC Candidates for First Year Engineering and Technology is prepared based on the marks or score secured by the candidate in the CET conducted by the Competent Authority or marks/score in any other examination conducted by the appropriate authority for admission to these courses.

questions: What are the tie-breaking rules for HSC Candidates for First Year Engineering and Technology?
answers: In case of a tie for HSC Candidates for First Year Engineering and Technology, the relative merit is resolved in the following order: (a) higher marks or score in Mathematics at CET; (b) higher marks or score in Physics at CET; (c) higher marks or score in Chemistry at CET; (d) higher percentage of marks in Board or qualifying examination for Physics, Mathematics, and Chemistry taken together; (e) higher percentage of marks in Mathematics at HSC or 10+2 Examination; (f) higher percentage of marks in Physics at HSC or 10+2 Examination; (g) higher percentage of marks in Aggregate at HSC or 10+2 Examination.

questions: How is the merit list prepared for NRI, OCI, PIO, and Foreign Students for First Year Engineering and Technology?

questions: What are the tie-breaking rules for NRI, OCI, PIO, and Foreign Students for First Year Engineering and Technology?

questions: Which institutions admit candidates through the Centralised Admission Process (CAP)?
answers: Unaided Private Professional Educational Institutions, Government, Government Aided institutes, University Departments, and University managed Institutions all admit candidates through the Centralised Admission Process (CAP).

questions: What is the first stage of the Centralised Admission Process (CAP)?
answers: The first stage of CAP is the display or publishing of the Information Brochure by the Competent Authority on its website. Candidates are advised to read it carefully.

questions: What are the initial steps for candidates participating in CAP?
answers: Candidates must fill out the Online Application Form and upload scanned images of valid, necessary original documents as per admission requirements.

questions: Is there an application fee for candidates applying for First Year Engineering and Technology, Planning, Pharmacy, etc., based on the Maharashtra State CET?
answers: No, eligible candidates aspiring for admission on the basis of CET conducted by the Competent Authority of Maharashtra State do not have to pay an application fee.

questions: Do candidates applying for admission based on National Level Examinations need to pay an application fee?
answers: Yes, eligible candidates aspiring for admission only on the basis of National Level Examinations (excluding Maharashtra State CET) must apply online and pay the required non-refundable fees online.

questions: What is the application fee for General Category candidates for First Year Engineering and Technology?
answers: The application fee for these candidates is ₹ 1000/-.

questions: What is the application fee for Reserved Category candidates for First Year Engineering and Technology?
answers: The application fee for these candidates is ₹ 800/-.

questions: What is the application fee for Children of NRI / OCI / PIO, Foreign National candidates for First Year Engineering and Technology?
answers: The application fee for these candidates is ₹ 5,000/-.

questions: What is the application fee for Direct Second Year Engineering and Technology, Pharmacy, HMCT for General Category candidates?
answers: The application fee for these candidates is ₹ 1000/-.

questions: Are application processing fees refundable?
answers: No, the application processing fee is non-refundable.

questions: What is the role of Facilitation Centers in the CAP process?
answers: Facilitation Centers are published on the website and facilitate candidates in filling the Online Application Form, scanning, and uploading required documents.

questions: Can candidates edit their application form after submission?
answers: Candidates can edit/update the information in their application form before they confirm it at any Facilitation Centre. After confirmation, information cannot be changed by the candidate.

questions: What is required during document verification at the Facilitation Centre?
answers: It is mandatory for the candidate to produce all original documents in support of the claim made in the application form during document verification.

questions: What are the stages related to merit lists in CAP?
answers: The stages involve the display of Provisional merit list, submission of grievances (if any), and finally, the display or publishing of Final Merit Lists.

questions: What is the significance of the merit list?
answers: The merit list gives the relative position of the candidate but does not guarantee admission to any course/institute.

questions: What information is displayed before each CAP Round regarding seat availability?
answers: Before each CAP Round, the Competent Authority publishes information on the website about institutes, courses offered, sanctioned intake, and the number of seats available for each category (Seat Matrix).

questions: How many choices of Institutes and Courses can a candidate fill in the online option form?
answers: Candidates can fill in a minimum of 1 and a maximum of 300 choices of Institutes and Courses in decreasing order of their preference.

questions: Is it mandatory to fill the Online Option Form to participate in CAP?
answers: Yes, in order to participate in the CAP (subject to fulfillment of eligibility requirements), it is MANDATORY to fill the Online Option Form for the respective CAP Round.

questions: Can candidates change their options after confirming the online option form?
answers: No, after confirmation of the Option Form, the candidate will not be able to change the Options.

questions: How is a confirmed option form indicated?
answers: The serial number of the block in the option form indicates the preference of choice, with block No. 1 being the highest priority. The candidate must re-enter their Application ID and Password to confirm the submitted online Option Form.

questions: What happens if a candidate is allotted their first preference in CAP Round-I?
answers: If a candidate is allotted the seat as per their first preference in CAP Round-I, such allotment is auto-freezed, and the candidate must accept it. They will not be eligible for subsequent CAP rounds. They must then report to the ARC for document verification or self-scrutinize documents online and pay the seat acceptance fee, then report to the allotted institute for admission. Failure to do so forfeits the seat.

questions: What options does a candidate have if they are allotted a seat other than their first preference in CAP Round-I?
answers: If a candidate is allotted a seat other than their first preference in CAP Round-I, they can either 'freeze' the offered seat if satisfied and not wish to participate in further rounds (requiring reporting to ARC/self-scrutiny and fee payment, leading to final allotment), or they can accept the seat for 'betterment' in subsequent rounds by reporting to ARC/self-scrutinizing documents. If they do not accept the seat, they are still eligible for subsequent rounds.

questions: Who is eligible to participate in CAP Rounds II, III, and IV?
answers: Candidates who were eligible for betterment from previous rounds, candidates who have not been allotted any seat in previous rounds, and candidates who did not participate (failed to fill option form) in previous rounds are eligible for CAP Rounds II, III, and IV.

questions: In CAP Rounds II and III, what happens if a candidate is allotted a higher preference?
answers: Candidates who have been allotted a seat other than their first preference in Round-I, first three preferences in Round-II, or first six preferences in Round-III and accepted it, when filling a fresh option form for the subsequent round, need not fill the preference already allotted. If an upward preference is allotted, their earlier seat allotment is automatically cancelled. If no upward preference is allotted, their previous allotment is retained.

questions: What happens if a candidate is allotted their first three preferences in Round-II or first six preferences in Round-III?
answers: If a candidate is allotted their first three preferences in Round-II or first six preferences in Round-III, such allotment is auto-freezed, and they must accept it. They will not be eligible for subsequent CAP rounds. They must report to ARC/self-scrutinize documents and pay the seat acceptance fee, then report to the allotted institute for admission. Failure to do so forfeits the seat, and this allotment is final.

questions: Is there a betterment option after Round IV?
answers: No, there shall be no further betterment option available to the candidate after Round IV. The allotment made and/or allotment retained in Round IV shall be final. For Working Professionals, there is no further betterment option after Round II.

questions: What happens if a candidate fails to produce original documents during admission reporting?
answers: If a candidate has been allotted a seat based on a claim in the application but fails to produce supporting documents, the allotment will automatically be cancelled, and the seat will become available for allotment in further rounds.

questions: Can a candidate rectify errors in their application form at the time of document scrutiny at ARC?
answers: Yes, candidates are entitled to rectify certain errors at ARC, including: change of gender, error in marks obtained (though change in merit number due to increased marks is not permitted), error in caste/sub-caste/reserved category (but not change from General to Reserved Category), and removal of minority, disability, defence, orphan, or TFWS status due to lack of supporting documents, change in Type of Candidature for Maharashtra State, change in Home University, and change in qualification. No other changes are allowed.

questions: Can a candidate change from a General Category to a Reserved Category at the time of document scrutiny?
answers: No, a candidate shall in no case be allowed to change from General to Reserved Category. However, a reserved category candidate can change to General if they fail to submit requisite documents.

questions: What is the process after a candidate is finally allotted an institution?
answers: The candidate must report to the finally allotted institution and confirm their admission as per the schedule. The Institute will verify required documents, upload the admission in the online system, and issue a system-generated receipt of confirmation to the candidate.

questions: How are fees determined for Government, Government Aided Institutes, and University Managed Engineering/Technology Degree Courses?
answers: Fee structure for these institutes is prescribed by the Government of Maharashtra from time to time.

questions: How are fees determined for Unaided Private Professional Educational Institutions?
answers: The Adhoc / Interim fee structure is approved by the Fee Regulating Authority. The final fee approved and published by the Fee Regulating Authority for that year is the fee payable by the candidate.

questions: What concessions are available for Backward Class Category and Economically Weaker Section Candidates belonging to Maharashtra State only?
answers: For SC/ST/VJDTNT(A)/NT(B)/NT(C)/NT(D)/SBC/OBC/SEBC and EWS category candidates, schemes/modes of concessions and loan scholarships (if any) in tuition and other fees will be announced by the Central/State Government. These candidates will receive the amount of waiver notified in government circulars, subject to fulfilling norms and conditions.

questions: What fees do Jammu & Kashmir and Ladakh Migrant Candidates and North East and Union Territory Candidates admitted by appropriate authority pay?
answers: These candidates pay the fees applicable to Non Autonomous Government institutes (as given in 9(5)(a)), plus additional fees prescribed by the concerned University from time to time.

questions: What is the primary method of seat allotment under CAP for Maharashtra State Candidature Candidates?
answers: All seats (Open, Reserved, Male, Female) for Maharashtra State Candidature Candidates are allotted based on their Inter-Se-Merit in Stage-I of the computerized allotment process.

questions: How are Economically Weaker Section (EWS) and Orphan candidates considered for seat allotment?
answers: EWS and Orphan candidates are first considered for seats reserved for them as per their Inter-Se-Merit. If no seats are available in their reserved category, they are then considered for allotment in the General Category based on their Inter-Se-Merit.

questions: How are Reserved Class category candidates considered for General Category seats?
answers: Reserved Class category candidates are considered for allotment in General Category seats by virtue of their Inter-Se-Merit, or in their respective category of reservation if General Category seats are not available at their merit.

questions: How are Special Backward Class (SBC) category candidates considered for allotment?
answers: SBC category candidates are considered for allotment in the General Category by virtue of their merit. If they were in a Reserved Class prior to inclusion in the SBC category, they are also considered in their original Reserved Class category.

questions: How are seats allotted to Persons with Disability (PWD) category candidates?
answers: Allotment to PWD candidates is within their respective Reserved or General category only. Earmarked seats for PWD are allotted as per their Inter-Se-Merit if the calculated number is a complete integer. Other available PWD seats are allotted from a combined list of all PWD candidates based on Inter-Se-Merit, with a maximum of one seat from the same reserved category.

questions: What happens if the total available seats for a Reserved or General category for PWD candidates are less than two?
answers: If the total available seats for a Reserved or General category are less than two, no seat will be allotted to a Person with Disability category candidate for that specific course.

questions: How are seats allotted to Defence category candidates?
answers: Allotment to Defence Category Candidates is within their respective Reserved or General category only. Earmarked seats for Defence category are allotted as per their Inter-Se-Merit if the calculated number is a complete integer. Other available Defence category seats are allotted from a combined list of all Defence Category candidates based on Inter-Se-Merit, with a maximum of one seat from the same reserved category.

questions: What happens if the total available seats for a Reserved or General category for Defence candidates are less than two?
answers: If the total available seats for a Reserved or General category are less than two, no seat will be allotted to a Defence category candidate for that specific course.

questions: In what sequence is seat allotment done if a seat is available for a candidate in more than one category?
answers: If a seat is available in more than one category, allotment is done in the following sequence: (i) Orphan, (ii) Ladies, (iii) Persons with Disability candidates, (iv) Defence.

questions: What happens in Stage II of allotment for Female to Male Candidates?
answers: If seats reserved for Female Candidates of the Reserved Class category or General Category remain vacant, such seats are then allotted to Male candidates belonging to the respective Reserved Class or General Category.

questions: How are Special Backward Class (SBC) category candidates considered in Stage III of allotment?
answers: If Reserved class category seats remain vacant after previous stages, such seats are considered for allotment to SBC Category candidates, limited to the extent of two percent of seats.

questions: What happens in Stage IV of allotment?
answers: In Stage IV, seats are considered for allotment to all candidates based on Inter-Se-Merit, without any specific type of reservation.

questions: What happens in Stage V of allotment?
answers: In Stage V, any remaining vacant seats are allotted to All India Candidates. For Direct Admission to Second Year (Lateral Entry) of Engineering and Technology, vacant seats are filled based on Inter-Se-Merit of Diploma in Engineering candidates, then Bachelor of Science candidates, and finally D. Voc. candidates.

questions: What is the order of preference for First year admissions in Stage VI if seats remain vacant after Stage V?
answers: If seats remain vacant after Stage V for First year admissions, they are allotted in the following order of preference as per eligibility: (i) Diploma Candidates based on Inter-Se-Merit; (ii) D.Voc. Candidates based on Inter-Se-Merit.

questions: Which reservations are not applicable for Post Graduate Courses?
answers: For Post Graduate Courses, Female, Orphan, and Defence reservations are not applicable.

questions: How is admission done for All India Candidature Candidates for First Year Engineering and Technology and Master of Engineering and Technology (Integrated)?
answers: Admission is based on JEE (Main) or NEET. If seats remain vacant, then CET score, then Diploma in Engineering marks, and then D.Voc. marks are considered, in that order.

questions: How is admission done for All India Candidature Candidates for First Year Hotel Management and Catering Technology, Computer Applications (BCA), Management (BBA/BMS/BBM etc.), etc. (Under Graduate courses)?
answers: Admission is based on NCI-IM JEE/Common University Entrance Test (CUET) UG. If seats remain vacant, then CET Score, and then D. Voc. marks are considered.

questions: How is admission done for All India Candidature Candidates for First Year Planning and Master of Planning (Integrated)?
answers: Admission is based on JEE (Main) B. Planning. If seats remain vacant, then CET score, then D. Voc. marks, and if seats still remain vacant, then HSC or 10+2 examination marks are considered.

questions: How is admission done for All India Candidature Candidates for First Year Design?
answers: Admission is based on the score of the Undergraduate Common Entrance Examination (CET) for Design (UCEED) conducted by IIT. If seats remain vacant, then D. Voc. marks are considered.

questions: How is admission done for All India Candidature Candidates for First Year Pharmacy and Pharm D.?
answers: Admission is based on NEET. If seats remain vacant, then CET score is considered.

questions: How is admission done for All India Candidature Candidates for First Year Bachelor of Pharmacy (Practice)?
answers: Admission is based on marks or score secured in the Qualifying Examination.

questions: How is admission done for All India Candidature Candidates for First Year Architecture?
answers: Admission is based on the score in an aptitude test in architecture (JEE conducted by NTA or NATA conducted by the Council of Architecture) and HSC or 10+2 Marks.

questions: How is admission done for All India Candidature Candidates for First Year Management (Post Graduate courses)?
answers: Admission is based on the percentile score in CET conducted by the Competent Authority, Common Admission Test (CAT) conducted by IIM, and Common Management Aptitude Test (CMAT) conducted by NTA.

questions: How is admission done for All India Candidature Candidates for First Year Pharmacy (Post Graduate courses)?
answers: Admission is based on the Graduate Pharmacy Aptitude Test (GPAT) Score conducted by NTA.

questions: How are Minority Quota Seats allotted?
answers: Minority quota seats in minority institutions (linguistic or religious) are first allotted to respective minority candidates. If seats remain vacant, they are allotted to Maharashtra State candidature candidates. If still vacant, they are allotted to All India candidature candidates.

questions: How are Supernumerary seats for Jammu and Kashmir as well as Ladakh Migrant Candidature candidates allotted?
answers: These seats are allotted based on Inter-Se-Merit in the Entrance test conducted by the appropriate authority. If seats remain vacant, they are then allotted based on CET conducted by the Competent Authority.

questions: Can candidates whose names do not appear in the merit list participate in the admission process for Jammu and Kashmir and Ladakh Migrant Candidature?
answers: No, candidates whose names do not appear in the merit list(s) will not be able to participate in the entire Admission Process for Jammu and Kashmir and Ladakh Migrant Candidature.

questions: What happens if a candidate admitted under the Jammu and Kashmir and Ladakh Migrant Candidature provision wishes to change their course or college?
answers: Candidates admitted under this provision are not allowed to change course or college in any year of study.

questions: For which courses are Jammu and Kashmir and Ladakh Migrant Candidature seats available?
answers: These seats are available only for admission to the First Year of Under Graduate Courses as well as Post Graduate courses in Management and Computer Application.

questions: What is required to confirm admission at the allotted institute?
answers: Candidates must confirm admission by paying the requisite fee and submitting required original documents to the respective institute as per schedule.

questions: What happens if a candidate fails to substantiate claims made at the time of submitting necessary original documents?
answers: If a candidate fails to substantiate claims made at the time of submitting necessary original documents within the reporting time for the CAP Round, the candidate forfeits the claim on the allotted seat.

questions: What should a candidate do if they cannot produce original certificates at the time of admission due to having secured admission elsewhere?
answers: If a candidate is unable to produce original certificates because they are retained by another institution where they have already taken admission, they must produce a certificate from the Head of that institution stating that admission has been secured and original certificates are retained. Attested copies of certificates, duly attested by the Head of the concerned institution, must be produced. Fees must be paid immediately, and candidates will be permitted to submit the required original documents later.

Attested copies of certificates, duly attested by the Head of the concerned institution, must be produced. Fees must be paid immediately, and candidates will be permitted to submit the required original documents later.

questions: How are seats allotted in CAP Rounds I, II, III, and IV?
answers: Seats in CAP Rounds I, II, III, and IV are allotted through a computerized process.

questions: What happens to a vacant seat if it's not allotted or if the allotted candidate doesn't report?
answers: If a seat remains vacant due to non-allotment and non-reporting, it will be considered for allotment in the subsequent round.

questions: How are Home University (HU) and Other than Home University (OHU) seats handled in CAP Rounds?
answers: Every stage in CAP Rounds I, II, III, and IV is first executed with HU and OHU tags. If seats remain vacant, the same stage is then executed without HU and OHU tags.

questions: What happens if seats remain vacant after the HU/OHU and non-HU/OHU execution of stages?
answers: If seats still remain vacant for any reason in the specified rules (sub-rules (1), (2), and (3) of rule 7), they are considered for allotment to all eligible candidates as per sub-rules (1), (2), and (3) of rule 5, irrespective of the seat type, based on Inter-Se-Merit.

questions: What is the preference order for seat allotment in Minority Institutions during CAP Round I?
answers: For Minority Institutions in CAP Round I, the allotment preference is: (i) Stage I of sub-rule (3) of rule 10 (Minority Quota), (ii) Stages I and II of sub-rule (1) of rule 10 (Maharashtra State Candidature, including general and female reservations), (iii) Sub-rule (2) of rule 10 (All India Candidature).

questions: What is the preference order for seat allotment in institutions *other than* Minority Institutions during CAP Round I?
answers: For institutions other than Minority Institutions in CAP Round I, the allotment preference is: (i) Stages I and II of sub-rule (1) of rule 10 (Maharashtra State Candidature, including general and female reservations), (ii) Sub-rule (2) of rule 10 (All India Candidature).

questions: What is the preference order for seat allotment in Minority Institutions during CAP Rounds II and III?
answers: For Minority Institutions in CAP Rounds II and III, the allotment preference is: (i) Stage I of sub-rule (3) of rule 10 (Minority Quota), (ii) Stages I to IV of sub-rule (1) of rule 10 (Maharashtra State Candidature, including general, female, SBC, and no-reservation stages), (iii) Stage II of sub-rule (3) of rule 10 (Vacant Minority Quota seats to Maharashtra State candidates), (iv) Sub-rule (2) of rule 10 (All India Candidature), (v) Stage III of sub-rule (3) of rule 10 (Further vacant Minority Quota seats to All India candidates).

questions: What is the preference order for seat allotment in institutions *other than* Minority Institutions during CAP Rounds II and III?
answers: For institutions other than Minority Institutions in CAP Rounds II and III, the allotment preference is: (i) Stages I to IV of sub-rule (1) of rule 10 (Maharashtra State Candidature, including general, female, SBC, and no-reservation stages), (ii) Sub-rule (2) of rule 10 (All India Candidature).

questions: What is the preference order for seat allotment in Minority Institutions during CAP Round IV?
answers: For Minority Institutions in CAP Round IV, the allotment preference is: (i) Stage I of sub-rule (3) of rule 10 (Minority Quota), (ii) Stages I to V of sub-rule (1) of rule 10 (Maharashtra State Candidature, including general, female, SBC, no-reservation, and All India Candidates), (iii) Stage II of sub-rule (3) of rule 10 (Vacant Minority Quota seats to Maharashtra State candidates), (iv) Sub-rule (2) of rule 10 (All India Candidature), (v) Stage III of sub-rule (3) of rule 10 (Further vacant Minority Quota seats to All India candidates), (vi) Stage VI of sub-rule (1) of rule 10 (Diploma/D.Voc. Candidates for First Year admissions if applicable).

questions: What is the preference order for seat allotment in institutions *other than* Minority Institutions during CAP Round IV?
answers: For institutions other than Minority Institutions in CAP Round IV, the allotment preference is: (i) Stages I to V of sub-rule (1) of rule 10 (Maharashtra State Candidature, including general, female, SBC, no-reservation, and All India Candidates), (ii) Sub-rule (2) of rule 10 (All India Candidature), (iii) Stage VI of sub-rule (1) of rule 10 (Diploma/D.Voc. Candidates for First Year admissions if applicable).

questions: How are allotments carried out in CAP Rounds I, II, III, and IV for Home University, Other than Home University, and State Level Seats?
answers: Allotment in CAP Rounds I, II, III, and IV for Home University Seats, Other than Home University seats, and State Level Seats is carried out as per the Inter-Se-Merit of Candidates having Maharashtra State Candidature. Seats are allotted based on Inter-Se-Merit, options filled, and seat availability at that point in time.

questions: Are candidates who have already been allotted a seat considered for subsequent stages of allotment?
answers: Yes, all candidates eligible for a particular stage of allotment are considered for a seat in that stage, even if they have been allotted or not allotted a seat in the previous stage.

questions: Can a candidate's allotment change during a CAP round?
answers: Yes, during the allotment of any stage, a candidate may get an upward shift in the allotment with reference to the options filled by them, according to the availability of seats at that point in time.

questions: Are there reservations under different categories in Unaided Professional Educational Institutions?
answers: No, there are no reservations under different categories in an Unaided Professional Educational Institution for allocation of seats stated in sub-rules (2), (3), (4) and (5) of rule 7, as well as in Sponsored Category seats.

questions: Are Reserved Category Candidates considered for all stages of allotment?
answers: Yes, all Reserved Category Candidates (including SBC in their original Category) are considered for allotment in all stages.

questions: What happens to seats that become vacant due to upward shifts?
answers: Due to upward shifts, the seats falling vacant are considered for allotment in further iterations of the same stage as per the provisions of that stage of allotment.

questions: How is the final allotment determined?
answers: The allotment against the first available option in the order of preference filled in by the candidate is retained as the final allotment.

questions: How are candidates informed about their provisional allotment?
answers: The allotment list displayed on the website shows the provisional allotment offered to the candidates. No personal communication or allotment letters are issued.

questions: What is the process for accepting an allotted seat?
answers: A candidate who has been allotted a seat must download the 'Provisional Seat Allotment Letter.' They then pay a seat acceptance fee through online mode, or by self-scrutiny of documents uploaded online, or by a demand draft at the Admission Reporting Centre. The seat is confirmed by the Reporting Centre after document verification and eligibility checks, and an online receipt of acceptance is issued.

questions: What is the seat acceptance fee and is it refundable?
answers: The seat acceptance fee is Rupees one thousand only for all admitted candidates, and it is a non-refundable processing fee.

questions: What happens if a candidate fails to report for seat acceptance?
answers: Failure to report for seat acceptance is considered as if the candidate has rejected the offer.

questions: Under what circumstances can an allotted seat be cancelled?
answers: An allotted seat is cancelled if, at any time, any document or certificate is found to be invalid or fraudulent, and/or the candidate does not meet the eligibility norms.

questions: How can a candidate reject an allocated seat and still be considered for subsequent rounds?
answers: Candidates who want to reject an allocated seat can do so by not remitting the seat acceptance fee at the Reporting Centre or by not completing the self-scrutiny of documents uploaded online. To be considered for subsequent rounds, they must submit a fresh option form for that round as per the schedule.

questions: What happens if information provided by a candidate in their application is found to be false or incorrect?
answers: If any statement or information in the application form is found to be false or incorrect in any material particular, the Principal will cancel the admission and forfeit the fees. An appeal can be preferred to the Competent Authority within seven days, and the decision of the Competent Authority is final.

questions: How are complaints regarding fake certificates handled?
answers: Complaints regarding the use of fake certificates are investigated in a time-bound manner. If found true, the admission is cancelled, and appropriate action is initiated with intimation to the Competent Authority.

questions: What is the typical class timing for courses reserved for Working Professionals?
answers: The timings for the conduct of classes for Working Professionals are normally in the evening hours or any flexible convenient timings in alignment with the timings of their Industry/Organization.

questions: What is the mode of conduct for classes for Working Professionals?
answers: The mode of conduct of classes for Working Professionals is as applicable for Regular Programs, defined as Regular Face to Face Mode as per AICTE Public Notice.

questions: Is there a reserved seat for candidates from Central Government Organizations/Industries/Companies/Autonomous Organizations for Working Professionals?
answers: Yes, one seat in every Institute is reserved for candidates working in Central Government Organizations/Industries/Companies/Autonomous Organizations purely on MERIT Basis. If no such candidate is available, the vacant seat is transferred to the General Category.

questions: How many centralized admission rounds are conducted for Working Professionals?
answers: Only two centralized admission rounds are conducted for the admission of Working Professionals.

questions: What is the minimum admission requirement for a course for Working Professionals to run?
answers: The minimum admission required to run a course for Working Professionals is one-third of the sanctioned intake in each course.

questions: What happens if admissions to a course for Working Professionals are below one-third of the sanctioned intake after the pre-cut-off date?
answers: If admissions to a course for Working Professionals are below one-third of the sanctioned intake after the pre-cut-off date, the Competent Authority carries out re-allocation of candidates from these courses to courses having admissions not less than one-third of the sanctioned intake.

questions: What is the process for re-allocation of Working Professionals?
answers: The re-allocation process involves: stopping and freezing all admissions for Working Professionals at the pre-cut-off date, publishing vacancy positions, publishing lists of under-admitted courses and admitted candidates, allowing candidates to fill online preference forms for transfer, and re-allocating Working Professionals to other nearby institutes (within 50 km radial distance) strictly as per merit.

questions: What happens if a Working Professional candidate fails to participate in or report for the re-allocation process?
answers: Provisional admission of the candidate is automatically cancelled if they fail to submit and confirm the Preference Form for re-allocation, do not get a seat in the re-allocation process, or fail to report to the re-allocated institute as per schedule.

questions: When does the re-allocation process for Working Professionals occur?
answers: This re-allocation round is carried out between the pre-cut-off date and the cut-off date for admissions of Working Professionals only.

questions: What happens if a provisional admission for a Working Professional course with less than one-third admissions is cancelled or re-allocated?
answers: Courses in Institutes having admissions below one-third after the pre-cut-off date must refund full fees and original documents to the candidate immediately within two days from the cancellation of admission or re-allocation.

questions: What are the eligibility criteria for admission to Under Graduate / Post Graduate Dual Degree / Integrated Courses through collaborative / twinning mode?
answers: Eligibility for admission to these courses is the same as admission to the first year of respective professional Under Graduate / Post Graduate Dual Degree / Integrated Courses, plus any additional norms prescribed by the Appropriate Authority.

questions: Are Lateral Entry and supernumerary seats allowed in Foreign Collaboration and Twinning Programme?
answers: No, Lateral Entry and supernumerary seats are not allowed in Foreign Collaboration and Twinning Programme.

questions: Who prepares and displays the Inter-Se-Merit lists for Institution level admissions?
answers: The Institution, after verifying all required documents, prepares and displays the Inter-Se-Merit lists of candidates to be filled at the Institution level, in the Institutional Quota and Supernumerary Quota (for OCI/PIO, Foreign National, Children of Indian workers in Gulf Countries), along with vacant seats after CAP, on the notice board and institution website.

questions: When can a Minority or Non-Minority institution surrender its Institutional Quota seats to the CAP?
answers: A Minority or Non-Minority institution intending to surrender its Institutional Quota (in part or full) of specified courses to the CAP must communicate two days before the display of the seat matrix of CAP Round I. They are not allowed to surrender Institutional quota seats thereafter.

questions: How are admissions and cancellations updated?
answers: All admissions and cancellations must be updated immediately through the online system.

questions: How are CAP seats filled if they remain vacant after the CAP Rounds?
answers: If any CAP seat remains or becomes vacant after the CAP Rounds, it is first filled by a candidate from the same category for which it was earmarked during the CAP. If seats still remain vacant, they are filled on the basis of Inter-Se-Merit of the applicants.

questions: When filling vacant CAP seats, is preference given to Maharashtra State Candidature Candidates or All India Candidature Candidates?
answers: While filling these vacant seats, preference is given to the Maharashtra State Candidature Candidate over the All India Candidature Candidate on the basis of Inter-Se-Merit.

questions: What happens if seats remain vacant after exhausting Maharashtra State Candidature and All India Candidature Candidates?
answers: After exhausting Maharashtra State Candidature Candidates and All India Candidature Candidates, if any seats remain vacant in the sanctioned intake, these seats may be filled with NRI, Foreign Students (FS), Overseas Citizen of India (OCI), Persons of Indian Origin (PIO), Children of Indian Workers in the Gulf Countries (CIWGC) Candidature Candidates, provided the Institute has secured prior approval from the appropriate authority for these seats.

questions: Can a candidate apply for institution-level admission through the Competent Authority's website?
answers: Yes, if a candidate is unable to submit the application directly to the concerned institution, they have the opportunity to apply through the website of the Competent Authority until the date of allotment of the final CAP Round. These applications are forwarded to the respective institutions after the CAP Round IV allotment process.

questions: What is the responsibility of Unaided Private Professional Educational Institutions after completing the admission process?
answers: After completing the admission process, every Unaided Private Professional Educational Institution must submit the admission-approval proposal to the Director of Technical Education and the Admission Regulating Authority, in accordance with sub-section (5) of section 9 of the Act.

questions: What information should be included in the Admission-approval proposal?
answers: The Admission-approval proposal must include a list of all admitted candidates, detailing their quota, Candidature Type, Reservation, Qualification Marks, etc., along with the required documents of candidates admitted at the institution level.

questions: What is the institute's responsibility regarding the 'Academic Bank of Credits' portal?
answers: The Institute is responsible for enrolling the candidates on the portal of 'Academic Bank of Credits' within eight days after confirming their admission. The Institute must confirm the enrollment of the candidate on the 'Academic Bank of Credits' portal before submitting the admission approval proposal to the Directorate of Technical Education.

questions: What must the admission approval proposal include regarding the 'Academic Bank of Credits'?
answers: The admission approval proposal must consist of the list of admitted candidates along with the enrollment number of each candidate on the portal of 'Academic Bank of Credits'.

questions: Will admissions be recommended for approval if candidates are not enrolled on the 'Academic Bank of Credits' portal?
answers: No, admission of candidates will not be recommended for approval to the Admission Regulating Authority unless all admitted candidates in the institute are enrolled on the 'Academic Bank of Credits' portal.

questions: What happens if a minority institution fails to admit a minimum percentage of its sanctioned intake from the concerned minority for three consecutive years?
answers: If a minority institution fails to admit a minimum of fifty-one percent of its sanctioned intake from persons belonging to the concerned minority for a period of three consecutive years, the Competent Authority will inform the Department accordingly. The Department will then forward such cases along with observations to the Minorities Development Department, as per sub-section (2) of section 6 of the Act.

questions: How can a candidate cancel their admission?
answers: The candidate must apply online for cancellation and submit a duly signed copy of the system-generated application for cancellation of admission to the Institution. Once the online request is submitted, their admission is treated as cancelled.

questions: What happens to the seat once a candidate cancels their admission?
answers: Upon cancellation, the candidate loses the claim on the seat, and such seat becomes available for further allotment.

questions: What is the refund policy if a candidate cancels admission on or before the last day for full fee refund?
answers: If the candidate cancels admission on or before the last day for cancellation of seats with full fee refund (as specified by the Competent Authority), the Institute must refund the entire fees to the candidate after deducting Rupees one thousand only towards processing charges. All original documents submitted to the Institute must also be returned within two days from the submission of the duly signed system-generated application.

questions: Is a candidate entitled to a refund if they cancel admission after the last day for full fee refund?
answers: No, a candidate is not entitled to any refund of their fee, except for the Security Deposit and Caution Money Deposit, if the online cancellation is effected after the last day for cancellation of seats with full fee refund as specified by the Competent Authority.

questions: How can a candidate cancel admission after the cut-off date for online cancellation?
answers: The link for online cancellation for admission is deactivated after the cut-off date. After this date, the candidate has to apply for cancellation of admission directly to the Institute by submitting an application.

questions: Can an institution refuse to return a candidate's documents (certificates, degrees, etc.)?
answers: No institution, having possession or custody of any document (Certificates, Degree, Diploma, award, or other document) deposited by a person for admission, shall refuse to return such documents. This is to prevent compelling the person to pay fees for a course or program they do not intend to pursue or avail any facility.

questions: Can an institution recover fees for subsequent years from a student who cancels their admission?
answers: No, the Institution is not entitled to recover the fees for the subsequent years from a student seeking cancellation of their admission at any point in time.

questions: Is the submission of a duly signed copy of the system-generated application to the Institute mandatory for cancellation to be treated as final?
answers: While the candidate should submit the duly signed copy, the Institute shall consider the online request made by the candidate for cancellation as final, irrespective of whether they have submitted the duly signed copy to the Institute.

questions: When can a candidate seek a change in course or institution within the same institution?
answers: A candidate can seek a change in course or shift after successfully completing the First Year of studies or both first and second semester examination in all subjects, or if they failed in one of the heads of passing. This is subject to seat availability, and changes are based on the marks of the First Year or First and Second Semester together. The Principal is responsible for ensuring eligibility.

questions: Can a candidate transfer to another institution during the same academic year after being admitted in the first or second year?
answers: No, a candidate once admitted in the first or second year is not eligible for transfer to any other Institution during the same academic year.

questions: What are the eligibility criteria for a candidate to be considered for transfer of Institution or course after the first, second, or third year?
answers: A candidate passing the first year (both first and second semester) or second year (both third and fourth semester) or third year (both fifth and sixth semester) examinations in all subjects, or failed in one of the heads of passing, is considered eligible for transfer. For transfer after the second year, the candidate must have passed the first year, and for transfer after the third year, they must have passed the first and second year.

questions: Is transfer from Unaided Institutions to Government or Government Aided, University Departments, University Managed Institutions allowed?
answers: No, there shall be no transfer of students at any stage from Unaided Institutions to the Government or Government Aided, University Departments, University Managed Institutions.

questions: Can a candidate from a Government or Government Aided, University Department, or University Managed Institution transfer to an Unaided Educational Institution?
answers: Yes, a candidate from the Government or Government Aided, University Departments, University Managed Institution may seek transfer to an Unaided Educational Institution.

questions: Are student transfers allowed to Autonomous Institutions?
answers: No, there shall be no transfer of students at any stage to Autonomous Institutions.

questions: What is the process for transferring to Unaided Institutions?
answers: The Principals of Unaided institutions consider candidates from other institutions for transfer with prior approval from the Director of Technical Education. This requires the submission of a No Objection Certificate (NOC) from the original Institution, an Eligibility Certificate from the University, and information on vacancy position. The Principal or Director must ascertain the candidate's eligibility as per the concerned University's norms for the course of transfer.

questions: How do eligible candidates apply for transfer between Government or Government Aided, University Departments, and University Managed Institutions?
answers: Eligible candidates apply in writing to the Principal/Director of the institute where they studied their first year or second semester. The Principal/Director then forwards a consolidated branch-wise merit list of eligible candidates, including details like name, course, marks percentage, desired transfer courses and institutions, reasons for transfer, and remarks, along with course-wise vacancy positions, to the Director of Technical Education, Maharashtra State, as per the specified schedule.

questions: Will the Director of Technical Education entertain transfer applications without a recommendation from the Principal of the institution?
answers: No, no application without the recommendation of the Principal of the Institution shall be entertained by the Director of Technical Education.

questions: What happens if a university or institution's result is not declared before the transfer process?
answers: If the result of the University or Institution is not declared before the process of transfer, the candidate of that University or Institution shall lose their claim on transfer.

questions: Are candidates admitted under Supernumerary Quota seats eligible for change of Course or Institution?
answers: No, candidates admitted under Supernumerary Quota seats are not eligible for change of Course or Institution.

questions: Are candidates from professional educational institutions outside the purview of the Act eligible for transfer to unaided private professional educational institutions?
answers: Yes, candidates from professional educational institutions outside the purview of the Act are eligible for transfer to unaided private professional Educational Institutions, subject to fulfilling the eligibility criteria and requirements stipulated under sub-section (1) of section 3 of the Act, and the conditions stated in sub-rule (2).

questions: Who approves the list of all transfers?
answers: The Director of Technical Education communicates the list of all such transfers to the office of the Admissions Regulating Authority for final approval.

questions: What is the general requirement for submitting documents with the Application Form for Centralized Admission Process?
answers: Candidates are required to upload ALL Original Certificates/Documents in support of their claim at the time of filling up the Application Form for Admission. They must carry the original documents for scrutiny and verification at an identified Facilitation Centre.

questions: In what format and size should documents be scanned for upload?
answers: Candidates are required to scan the document in .jpg or .gif format with a minimum 150 dpi resolution and a file size of up to 1 MB.

questions: Do Facilitation Centers provide assistance with document scanning and uploading?
answers: Yes, Facilitation Centers assist candidates, free of cost, to scan and upload the documents.

questions: What are the common documents required for 'All Candidates'?
answers: 1. SSC (Std. X) mark sheet. 2. HSC/Diploma/B. Sc. mark sheet. 3. Qualifying Examination mark sheet. 4. Score Card Mark Sheet of CET examination such as JEE / NEET / NATA/ CUET / GATE / GPAT / NEEMS / UCEED etc. 5. School Leaving Certificate, if required to substantiate claim. 6. Certificate of the Indian Nationality of the candidate. 7. For Second Year Engineering and Technology, Pharmacy: Approval letter of Pharmacy Council of India given to the Institute.

questions: What additional document is required for Type–A Candidates?
answers: Domicile/Birth/Leaving certificate of the candidate indicating place of Birth in the State of Maharashtra.

questions: What additional document is required for Type–B Candidates?
answers: Domicile certificate of the candidate/father/mother of the candidate indicating that he/she is domiciled in the State of Maharashtra.

questions: What additional document is required for Type–C Candidates?
answers: Certificate from the employer in Proforma – A stating that the father/mother of the candidate, who is a Central Government / Government of India undertaking employee, is presently posted in Maharashtra.

questions: What additional document is required for Type–D Candidates?
answers: Certificate from the employer in Proforma – B stating that the father/mother of the candidate is a Maharashtra State Government / Maharashtra State Government undertaking employee. OR Undertaking along with documentary evidence from the retired employee stating the place of settlement.

questions: What additional documents are required for Type-E Candidates (Maharashtra Karnataka border area Candidates)?
answers: 1. Certificate stating that the candidate belongs to the Maharashtra Karnataka border area in Proforma – G1. 2. Certificate stating that the mother tongue of the candidate is Marathi in Proforma – G2.

questions: What additional documents are required for Backward class Candidates belonging to S.C. / S.T.?
answers: 1. Caste/Tribe certificate. 2. Caste/Tribe validity certificate.

questions: What additional documents are required for Backward class Candidates belonging to VJ/DT- NT(A)/ NT(B) / NT(C) / NT(D) /O.B.C/ SBC/SEBC?
answers: 1. Caste certificate. 2. Caste validity certificate. 3. Non creamy layer certificate valid up to 31st March 2026.

questions: What additional document is required for Economically Weaker Section (EWS) Candidates?
answers: Eligibility Certificate for Economically Weaker Section Proforma – V valid for 2025-26 (as per Government Resolution N. राआधो/4019 Ģ.N.31/16 अ, िदनांक 31.05.2021).

questions: What additional document is required for Orphan candidates?
answers: Orphan Certificate Proforma – U.

questions: What additional documents are required for Ex-Servicemen (Def-1)?
answers: 1. Defence Service Certificate Proforma – C. 2. Domicile certificate of father/mother who is an Ex-Service personnel is domiciled in the State of Maharashtra.

questions: What additional documents are required for Active Domicile Defence Candidates (Def-2)?
answers: 1. Defence Service Certificate Proforma – C. 2. Domicile certificate of father/mother who is an active defence service person is domiciled in the State of Maharashtra.

questions: What additional documents are required for Active Non Domicile Defence Candidates (Def-3)?
answers: 1. Defence Service Certificate Proforma – C and D/E. 2. Certificate from the employer in Proforma – D stating that father/mother of the candidate who is an active defence service person presently posted in Maharashtra. OR Certificate from the employer in Proforma – E stating that father/mother of the candidate who is an active defence service person and has retained the family in his previous place of posting in Maharashtra.

questions: What additional documents are required for Persons with Disability Candidates?
answers: 1. Certificate in the Proforma. 2. Domicile certificate of candidate.

questions: What additional documents are required for Union Territory of Jammu and Kashmir and Union Territory of Ladakh Migrant candidates?
answers: 1. Certificate of posting in case of defence and Government servants in Proforma – J. 2. Certificate of stay in refugee camp for those staying in camp in Proforma – K. 3. Certificate stating that the candidate belongs to displaced family Proforma – L. 4. Certificate stating that the candidate belongs to displaced family Proforma – M.

questions: What documents are required for Foreign nationals / Foreign Students?
answers: Documents notified, time to time, by the Competent Authority for admission to this quota.

questions: What documents are required for Persons of Indian Origin?
answers: Documents notified, time to time, by the Competent Authority for admission to this quota.

questions: What documents are required for Children of Indian Workers in Gulf Countries (CIWGC)?
answers: Documents notified, time to time, by the Competent Authority for admission to this quota.

questions: What documents are required for Non Resident Indian candidates?
answers: Documents notified, time to time, by the Competent Authority for admission to this quota.

questions: What additional document is required for TFWS candidates?
answers: Income certificate stating that his/her parent’s annual income is less than Rs. 8 Lakh from all sources, issued by the appropriate competent authority of the Maharashtra State.

questions: What additional documents are required for Minority Candidates?
answers: 1. Declaration of the Candidate for the respective Linguistic / Religious Minority Community or Leaving Certificate having information pertaining to Religion / Mother tongue as given in Proforma – O. 2. Domicile Certificate of Candidate or the documents specified for Maharashtra State Candidature Type A.

questions: What additional documents are required for Sponsored Candidates?
answers: Sponsorship Certificate Proforma – P and Proforma – Q.

questions: What additional documents are required for Working Professional candidates?
answers: 1. Experience Certificate for Working Professional Candidate from employer that certifies candidate have a minimum of ONE Year Full time / Regular working Experience (Proforma-W1). 2. Declaration from Working Professional candidate regarding Industry / Organization (Central / State) / Private / Public Limited Company / MSMEs being located within 50 KM radial distance from the admitting Institute; and regarding Reallocation process (Proforma-W2).

questions: What is the allocation of CAP seats for First Year of Under Graduate, Dual Degree and Integrated courses in Government/Government Aided Institutions, University Departments and SNDT University (excluding Minority Institutions)?
answers: For Autonomous institutions, it's 100% of sanctioned intake (State Level). For Non-Autonomous & University Departments, it's 70% for Home University (HU) and 30% for Other than Home University (OHU). There are no All India Seats, Institution Level Seats, or Minority Quota in these specific types of institutions.

questions: Are there any special seats within the sanctioned intake for Government/Government Aided Institutions, University Departments, and SNDT University?
answers: Yes, there are two seats per branch for Baba Harnam Singh of Langar Sahib Gurudwara Trust in SGGS Institute of Engineering and Technology, Nanded, and five seats for Seth Walchand Hirachand Memorial Trust & two seats for D.D. Daruwala Memorial in Walchand College of Engineering (WCE), Sangli. These seats are filled at the respective Institution level.

questions: What is the allocation of seats for the Institute of Chemical Technology Mumbai/Laxminarayan Innovation Technological University, Nagpur (LIT)?
answers: 70% of seats are for Maharashtra State Candidates (State Level) through CAP, and 30% are All India Seats. There are no Institution Level Seats or Minority Quota.

questions: What is the allocation of seats for Dr. Babasaheb Ambedkar Technological University Lonere?
answers: 85% of seats are for Maharashtra State Candidates (State Level), and 15% are for Candidates from Districts of Konkan Region (Thane, Raigad, Ratnagiri, Sindhudurg and Palghar). There are no All India Seats, Institution Level Seats, or Minority Quota.

questions: What is the allocation of CAP seats for Government/Government Aided Minority Colleges?
answers: For Autonomous institutions, it's 50% (State Level). For Non-Autonomous, it's 35% for HU and 15% for OHU. There are no All India Seats or Institution Level Seats from the general quota, but there is a 50% Minority Quota.

questions: What is the allocation of seats for COEP Technological University, Pune?
answers: 80% of seats are for Maharashtra State Candidates (State Level), and 20% are All India Seats. There are no Institution Level Seats or Minority Quota.

questions: What is the allocation of CAP seats for First Year of Unaided Private Professional Educational Institutions (excluding minority institutions)?
answers: For Autonomous institutions, it's 65% (State Level). For Non-Autonomous, it's 45.5% for HU and 19.5% for OHU. There are 15% All India Seats and 20% Institutional Quota (including 5% for NRI, if applicable). There is no Minority Quota in these.

questions: What is the allocation of CAP seats for First Year of Unaided Minority Educational Institutions?
answers: For Autonomous institutions, it's 100% of M.S. Seats (State Level). For Non-Autonomous, it's 70% of M.S. Seats for HU and 30% of M.S. Seats for OHU. There are 15% of seats under CAP for All India, a minimum of 51% (which can be extended up to 100% if declared to the Competent Authority) for Minority Quota, and 20% for Institutional Quota (which for Architecture and Pharmacy includes 5% NRI quota, convertible to All India Candidature if vacant).

questions: What is the allocation of CAP seats for Post Graduate Management Courses in Government/Government Aided Institutions, University Departments (excluding Minority Institutions)?
answers: For Autonomous, it's 85% Maharashtra State (State Level) and 15% All India Seats. For Non-Autonomous, it's 70% HU and 15% OHU for Maharashtra State and 15% All India Seats. There is no Minority Quota.

questions: What is the allocation of CAP seats for Post Graduate Management Courses in SNDT University and COEP Technological University, Pune?
answers: For both, it's 85% Maharashtra State (State Level) and 15% All India Seats. There is no Minority Quota.

questions: What is the allocation of CAP seats for Post Graduate Engineering and Technology, Hotel Management and Catering Technology, Pharmacy, Planning and Pharm. D.(Post Baccalaureate) Courses in Government/Government Aided Institutions, University Departments and COEP Technological University, Pune, Laxminarayan Innovation Technological University, Nagpur (Excluding Minority Institution)?
answers: 75% are Non-Sponsored Seats and 25% are Sponsored Seats for Maharashtra State Candidates. There are no All India Seats or Minority Quota.

questions: What is the allocation of CAP seats for Post Graduate Engineering and Technology, Hotel Management and Catering Technology, Pharmacy, Planning and Pharm. D.(Post Baccalaureate) Courses in Government/Government Aided Minority Educational Institutions?
answers: 37.5% are Non-Sponsored Seats and 12.5% are Sponsored Seats for Maharashtra State Candidates. 37.5% are Non-Sponsored Seats and 12.5% are Sponsored Seats for All India Candidates. No specific Minority Quota is listed here for these courses in this table.

questions: What is the allocation of CAP seats for First Year Computer Application Courses in Government/Government Aided Institutions?
answers: 70% are for HU and 30% for OHU for Maharashtra State Candidates. There are no All India Seats or Minority Quota.

questions: What is the allocation of CAP seats for First Year Computer Application Courses in University Departments?
answers: 70% HU and 15% OHU for Maharashtra State Candidates, and 15% All India Seats. There is no Minority Quota.

questions: What is the allocation of CAP seats for First Year Computer Application Courses in SNDT University?
answers: 85% are State Level for Maharashtra State Candidates, and 15% are All India Seats. There is no Minority Quota.

questions: What is the allocation of CAP seats for Architecture Courses in Government/Government Aided Institutions / University Department, excluding Minority Institutions?
answers: 100% for Maharashtra State Candidates. There are no All India Seats or Minority Quota.

questions: What is the allocation of CAP seats for Architecture Courses in Government/Government Aided Minority Educational Institution?
answers: 50% for Maharashtra State Candidates and 50% for Minority Quota. No All India Seats are listed for this type.

questions: What is the allocation of CAP seats for Post Graduate Management Courses in Unaided Private Professional Educational Institutions (Excluding minority institutions)?
answers: For Autonomous, it's 65% (State Level) for Maharashtra State Candidates. For Non-Autonomous, it's 45.5% for HU and 19.5% for OHU for Maharashtra State Candidates. There are 15% All India Seats, no Minority Quota, and 20% Institutional Quota.

questions: What is the allocation of CAP seats for Post Graduate Management Courses in Unaided Minority Educational Institutions?
answers: For Autonomous, it's 100% of M.S. Seats (State Level). For Non-Autonomous, it's 70% of M.S. Seats for HU and 30% of M.S. Seats for OHU. There are 15% of seats under CAP for All India, a minimum of 51% (which can be extended up to 100% if declared) for Minority Quota, and 20% for Institutional Quota.

questions: What is the allocation of CAP seats for Post Graduate Engineering and Technology, Pharmacy, Hotel Management and Catering Technology, Pharm. D.(Post Baccalaureate) and Planning Courses in Unaided Private Professional Educational Institutions (Excluding minority institutions)?
answers: 80% (60% Non-Sponsored and 20% Sponsored) for Maharashtra State Candidates. There are no All India Seats, no Minority Quota, and 20% Institutional Quota (15% Non-Sponsored and 5% Sponsored).

questions: What is the allocation of CAP seats for Post Graduate Engineering and Technology, Pharmacy, Hotel Management and Catering Technology, Pharm. D.(Post Baccalaureate) and Planning Courses in Unaided Minority Educational Institutions?
answers: 75% of M.S. Seats for Non-Sponsored and 25% of M.S. Seats for Sponsored (for Maharashtra State Candidature). There is a minimum of 51% (which can be extended up to 100% if declared) for Minority Quota, and 20% for Institutional Quota (15% Non-Sponsored and 5% Sponsored). No separate All India Seats are listed in this table for these types.

questions: What is the allocation of CAP seats for First Year Computer Application Courses in Unaided Private Professional Educational Institutions (Excluding minority institutions)?
answers: 45.5% for HU and 19.5% for OHU for Maharashtra State Candidates. There are 15% All India Seats, no Minority Quota, and 20% Institutional Quota.

questions: What is the allocation of CAP seats for First Year Computer Application Courses in Unaided Minority Educational Institutions?
answers: 70% of M.S. Seats for HU and 30% of M.S. Seats for OHU for Maharashtra State Candidates. There are 15% of seats under CAP for All India, a minimum of 51% (which can be extended up to 100% if declared) for Minority Quota, and 20% for Institutional Quota.

questions: What is the allocation of CAP seats for Architecture Courses in Unaided Private Professional Educational Institutions (Excluding minority institutions)?
answers: 80% for Maharashtra State Candidates. There are no All India Seats, no Minority Quota, and 20% Institutional Quota.

questions: What is the allocation of CAP seats for Architecture Courses in Unaided Minority Educational Institutions?
answers: 100% of M.S. Seats (for Maharashtra State Candidature). There is a minimum of 51% (which can be extended up to 100% if declared) for Minority Quota, and 20% for Institutional Quota. No separate All India Seats are listed in this table for this type.

questions: What is the allocation of Supernumerary Seats for Jammu and Kashmir as well as Ladakh Migrant Candidates?
answers: The number of seats for this quota is as per the policy of the Government.

questions: What is the allocation of Supernumerary Seats for OCI/PIO, Foreign Students and Children of Indian Workers in Gulf Countries candidates?
answers: 15% of the sanctioned intake seats or as prescribed by the appropriate authority from time to time (if applicable), to be filled by the Institution.

questions: What are Lateral Entry Seats for Direct Admission to Second Year of Under Graduate courses?
answers: Lateral Entry Seats are 10% of the Sanctioned Intake for Engineering/Technology, Hotel Management and Catering Technology, and Pharmacy. These seats are over and above the Sanctioned Intake and are Supernumerary to the approved Intake.

questions: What do 'Vacant Seats' include for Direct Second Year Admissions?
answers: 'Vacant Seats' include seats within the sanctioned intake that remained vacant during previous years, and EWS Seats that remained vacant during the previous year (considered for Lateral Entry to Second Year Course(s) to EWS Candidates).

questions: How are seats allocated for Direct Second Year Working Professionals?
answers: These seats are as sanctioned by the Appropriate Authority from time to time.

questions: What is the seat distribution for Direct Second Year in Government/Government Aided Institutions, University Department, SNDT University and COEP Technological University, Pune (Excluding Minority Institutions)?
answers: 100% of (Lateral Entry Seats + Vacant Seats) are General Seats. There is no Minority Quota. These seats are available for Maharashtra State Candidature Candidates only.

questions: What is the seat distribution for Direct Second Year in Dr. Babasaheb Ambedkar Technological University Lonere?
answers: 100% of (Lateral Entry Seats + Vacant Seats) are General Seats. There is no Minority Quota. These seats are available for Maharashtra State Candidature Candidates only.

questions: What is the seat distribution for Direct Second Year in Government/Government Aided Minority Institution?
answers: 50% of (Lateral Entry Seats + Vacant Seats) are General Seats and 50% of (Lateral Entry Seats + Vacant Seats) are for Minority Quota. These seats are available for Maharashtra State Candidature Candidates only.

questions: What is the seat distribution for Direct Second Year in Unaided Private Professional Educational Institutions (Excluding minority)?
answers: 100% of (Lateral Entry Seats + Vacant Seats) are General Seats through CAP. There is no Minority Quota or All India Quota for these seats. For Working Professionals, 65% of Sanctioned Intake are General Seats through CAP, with no Minority Quota, 15% All India Quota, and 20% Institute Level Quota.

questions: What is the seat distribution for Direct Second Year in Unaided Minority Educational Institutions?
answers: 100% of (Lateral Entry Seats + Vacant Seats) minus the Minority Quota are CAP Seats. There is a Minimum 51% Minority Quota (which can be extended up to 100% if declared). There is no All India Quota or General Institute Level Quota for these. For Working Professionals, 85% of Seats under CAP are available, with a Minimum 51% Minority Quota and 15% All India Seats under CAP. There is a 20% Institutional Quota.

questions: How are seats distributed for Direct Second Year Admission for Post Graduate courses (Lateral Entry) in Government/Government Aided Institutions / University Department (excluding Minority Institutions)?
answers: 100% of the *Vacant Seats (which are seats within the sanctioned intake that remained vacant during previous years) are General Seats, to be filled at the Institute Level. There is no Minority Quota.

questions: How are seats distributed for Direct Second Year Admission for Post Graduate courses (Lateral Entry) in Unaided Private Professional Educational Institutions (excluding minority Institutions)?
answers: 100% of the *Vacant Seats are General Seats, to be filled at the Institute Level. There is no Minority Quota.

How direct 2nd year admission distribution of seats is done?
